{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3537961,"name":"Darren Miller","username":"darrenleomiller","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/darrenleomiller/{size}/10270_2.png","created_at":"2025-02-24T15:03:00.369Z","cooked":"

The doc for the Advantage Kit TalonFX Swerve template says

The AdvantageKit template requires different feedforward gains than CTRE’s default swerve code, because it applies the swerve gear ratio using the TalonFX firmware and not on the RIO.

I don’t see where in the code this is getting done. Am I blind or is the doc maybe out of date?

This is relevant to us because we have a couple of drivetrain options and would like to use the same constants files if possible. We have a nice factory pattern that allows us to do so with a bit of Java Reflection, but we’ll need to adjust the scales somewhere if they are in fact different.

Thanks.

The template configures the gear ratio on the drive TalonFX here , which affects the scale of the feedforward gains. I can’t directly reference CTRE’s latest code, but my understanding is that this conversion is applied on the RIO instead of the Talon FX. You are of course welcome to customize the AdvantageKit template to change this behavior if you prefer to calculate gear ratios on the RIO.

darrenleomiller:

we have a couple of drivetrain options

I’m not sure what you mean by this exactly. The difference in feedforward gains would only be relevant if you were switching between the AdvantageKit template and CTRE’s swerve library. These are fundamentally different approaches that cannot be intermixed. The AdvantageKit template is only appropriate if you’re specifically trying to use log replay, and CTRE’s swerve library is appropriate for everything else.

Thanks, Jonah. I appreciate the thread, and will take a look at that shortly.

To the question of multiple drivetrain options, I agree it doesn’t make sense to intermix these in a single iteration, but we can swap between variations of, say, a homegrown drive implementation, YAGSL, and CTRE’s generated code by changing a line in a config file.

Now we can include the AdvantageKit TalonFX implementation as well.

We also have separately tuned constants for, say, torqueFOC control vs voltage control and can choose these subtypes without changing code.

There are a number of different reasons we do this, ranging from training and debugging to not putting all our eggs in one basket.

For example, we can rule out (or in) certain kinds of problems by switching to another implementation strategy. Similarly, by examining differences in the implementation details the students can explore different approaches while being able to switch back to a more stable or less complex implementation without code changes.

Thanks again for the pointer,

Darren
